data.title: The 100 Best Albums of 2017
data.meta_description: The Noisey staff's favorite releases of the year.
data.text:
Below are the 100 best albums of 2017 as chosen by the Noisey staff. Listen to songs from these albums on Apple Music and Spotify. See also: The 100 Best Songs of 2017.

What does getting older sound like? What does reconciling relationships sound like? Well, in Mac DeMarcoâ€™s world, all of those milestones sound really, really chill, if a little sad. This Old Dog deals with some very real themes. â€œMy Old Manâ€ is a song about how, increasingly, DeMarco sees shades of father in himself, though his dad was an alcoholic who was mostly absent from his life. The album is a meditation on growing up, falling in and out of love, and coming to terms with his relationship with his father, who came back into his life following a cancer diagnosis (On â€œWatching Him Fadeâ€ he sings, â€œEven though we barely know each other, it still hurts watching him fade awayâ€). But for all of the seriousness of the subject matter, thanks to its guitar melodies and wobbly distortions, This Old Dog sounds like something youâ€™d want to listen to while looking at falling leaves on a fall day in rural Vermont. DeMarco is known for his wacky humor, but with This Old Dog, heâ€™s shed some of the silliness and gotten a little more serious. Thatâ€™s what happens when you grow up. â€”Leslie Horn

As the daughter of the man many consider to be the greatest French songwriter of all time, Charlotte Gainsbourg has always said she felt like she had too much to live up to as a songwriter. On her previous records she handed those duties to others, singing witty, bleak tracks written by people like Beck and Pulpâ€™s Jarvis Cocker (incidentally, two descendants of her fatherâ€™s drolly hilarious style.) But after the tragic death of her sister Kate Barry, Gainsbourg felt a compulsion to write her own lyrics, even if she couldnâ€™t make them perfect. Rest, the resulting record, gets pretty damn close, facing down despair with an unflinching pen, tackling both Kateâ€™s passing as well her fatherâ€™s (who died when she was 19) in gruesome detail. On one song she recounts the strange experience of seeing the body of a loved one, describing, in French â€œa face of wax,â€ and â€œbare leg jutting out from under a sheet.â€ But the best songs feel strangely uplifting too. The producer SebastiAnâ€”who you may know as the French guy talking about Facebook on Frank Oceanâ€™s Blond(e)â€”gave much of the record an eerie lightness, informed by Gainsbourgâ€™s affinity for weepy disco and the crisp neon of synthy horror scores. Sheâ€™s called at least one of the songs â€œa ballad in a graveyard,â€ but the charms of Rest are in the willingness to capture the many sides of griefâ€”even in the worst times, sometimes you need to laugh, to dance. â€”Colin Joyce

Thundercatâ€™s Drunk is an oddball collection of music that blends 70s funk, a bit of ska, some punk, and a whole lot of anxiety. The recordâ€”23-tracks-long with most songs clocking in around two minutesâ€”sonically captures what itâ€™s like to be alive right now, perhaps better than any other release this year. Lyrically, Thundercat uses his soft falsetto to play around with absurdist humor, singing to cats while making love songs about drugs. The scattershot approach, bouncing from sound to sound (on top of guests like Kendrick Lamar and Wiz Khalifa, the musician taps yacht rock legends Michael McDonald and Kenny Loggins) is the ideal depiction of the millennial mind, uncertain of what itâ€™s supposed to be while clamoring at the heels of what it thought it once was. Do you like to spend your Saturdays getting hammered while talking about the end of the world? This is the album for you. â€”Eric Sundermann

In context, the title of Spencer Radcliffeâ€™s first full-band record is more of a taunt than its National Park-sloganeering may suggest. Across the album he employs a crew of friends to aid him in a creeping, apocalyptic take on the slowcore tropes heâ€™s come to love in his time as a songwriter. Guitars drone, swings swell ominously, drums crawl at a snailâ€™s pace as he paints a picture of the world where thereâ€™s smoke rising above the horizon and youâ€™re constantly on the run. In Radcliffeâ€™s oft-depressing worldview, concepts like truth, trust, and interpersonal love dissolve amidst the existential anxiety thatâ€™s part of being alive in this day and age, but you know, it sounds nice, making a case for at least a little hope. Itâ€™s one final postcard from a burning world, a solid argument for appreciating the simple things when the worldâ€™s ending. And the world is always ending. â€”Colin Joyce

Most bands over two decades into their careers have their best records long behind them, settling comfortably into greatest-hit compilations and victory lap tours. And then thereâ€™s Spoon, an act that, despite recent yearsâ€™ chorus of indie rock naysayers, arguably makes the best album of their career each time they put out a new album. Hot Thoughts builds on the brooding psychedelia introduced in 2014â€™s knockout They Want My Soul, and processes it through the funk and freak of frontman Britt Danielâ€™s hero Prince. The album departs from the relationship abstractions and observational storytelling of the bandâ€™s past work and instead offers a foray into Danielâ€™s idâ€”from its feverish title track, to the kaleidoscopic, hip-shaking â€œCan I Sit Next to You,â€ to the heaving, deconstructed jazz of the experimental closer â€œUs.â€ Thatâ€™s not say classic Spoon isnâ€™t thereâ€”the Austin actâ€™s trademark piano palettes and thick baselines still anchor the record, as does Danielâ€™s penchant for the political (â€œTear It Downâ€). But what theyâ€™ve forged with those roots is arguably their most sonically innovative work yetâ€”a strange new world that leaves us lingering. â€”Andrea Domanick

USBM mainstays Woe have come a long way since the bandâ€™s scrappy beginnings in frontman Chris Griggâ€™s Philadelphia bedroom in 2007. Over time, that raw solo project has morphed into an accomplished full band with an impressive touring history. Woeâ€™s fourth album, Hope Attrition, is a ferocious new entry in their pristine discography. Its riffs flash with surgical precision, slicing away the gloomier melodic touches that characterized the groupâ€™s origins and trimming any fat down to the bone. Grigg still holds the reins for the majority of Woeâ€™s songwriting, and his outside influences (punk, screamo, hardcore) havenâ€™t changed. But where previous releases centered around depression, religion, and Satan, this one makes no bones about the bandâ€™s disgust for fascism and white supremacy, especially in the magisterial fury of â€œNo Blood Has Honor.â€ Woe has always been relevant, but now, especially, they feel necessary. â€”Kim Kelly

For a moment, go with us to a summer rooftop party in Oakland. People are eating, drinking, and talking about the Aâ€™s and Cool Music. At some point during the night, space is cleared so local band RAYS can set up for a short set of their glorious indie pop. This event might solely be in our imagination, but RAYSâ€™ 26-minute blissful indie pop record is not. On the album, the four-piece trade in wiry and urgent post-punk and pop. Songs like â€œPain and Sorrowâ€ and â€œDead Mans Curveâ€ sound like lost Flying Nun singles while â€œTheatre of Lunacyâ€ is from a place where itâ€™s always sunny. Recorded by Bay-area stalwart Kelley Stoltz, and mastered by Australian Mikey Young (Ooga Boogas, Total Control, Eddy Current Suppression Ring), RAYS blends in elements of Pere Ubu, 80s New Zealand indie pop, and absurd humor. â€”Tim Scott

The Lisbon label Principe Discos has been an essential documentarian of an overlapping series of sounds and styles of contorted dance music issuing from the neighborhoods surrounding the city. But even in their vast catalog of high energy gems, thereâ€™s little exactly like the new record by the Bordeaux transplant NÃ­dia. Wrapping together her history as a dancer in Lisbonâ€™s kuduro scene and her affinity for off-kilter rhythms, NÃ­dia Ã© Ma, NÃ­dia Ã© Fudida moves with a wonderfully herky locomotion. Listening to tracks like â€œUnderground,â€ with its slot-machine synth sounds, muted guitar samples and stuttering drums, is a bit like watching someone try to footwork on a set of stiltsâ€”even when itâ€™s not exactly pretty, you can sense what a feat it is that theyâ€™re still upright at all. â€”Colin Joyce

At its heart, country music is the tradition of storytelling, preaching an unbiased inclusion of all those who have at some point in their lives been shunned for who they are (and often for the decisions theyâ€™ve made). Itâ€™s a place where sinners seek redemption and where misfits find kin. But, as Karen & the Sorrows point out on this record, it is still a narrow place, forbidding even the most basic indicators of â€œothernessâ€â€”sexuality, gender identity, class backgroundâ€”in favor of what many would see as a more traditional representation of a struggle. Take â€œTake Me For a Ride,â€ for example, which might be one of the first country songs about a woman going down on a woman in the back of a truck. The world is changing, though, and opening up a larger space for us to think about what country is or is not. With a nontraditional introduction to the genre and a nontraditional life experience, Karen & the Sorrows continue the legacy Lavender Country started, bringing a queer eye to country music, at once both upending tradition and continuing it. â€”Annalise Domenighini

In an interview last year, the Montreal-based composer Kara-Lis Coverdale said she was getting used to â€œbeing comfortable being uncomfortable,â€ which, incidentally, is a pretty neat summation of the experience of listening to Grafts. Itâ€™s a single 22-minute piece that relies largely on distant organ sounds and the healing chimes of electronics that sound like church bells and scrapyard thumb pianos. But where others would lean on these sounds for extended tone-setting drones, Coverdale flits between clusters of notes at a pretty rapid clip. If youâ€™ve ever watched high-speed footage of a hummingbird, itâ€™s sorta like that; sheâ€™s expending a lot of energy just to stay at rest. Thereâ€™s an inherent tension in this pacingâ€”your ear wants to relax, cued by the new agey palette, but it never really can. Just when you grow accustomed to a blissful melodic phrase, sheâ€™s moved onto something totally different. Somewhere in the constant motion, you can find stillness, you just have to work for it. â€”Colin Joyce

Obongjayarâ€™s second project Bassey is defined as an EP, but in terms of scope, visual richness and general completeness, it may as well be an albumâ€”one of wholeness and life, a story of heaven and hell and a journey between London and Nigeria, named after the derivation of the Igbo word for God. Navigating the dark and the light with hymn-like tones and instrumentation that sounds as though it comes from six feet beneath the ground, Bassey offers as much in statements as it does in a search inside of oneself for the truth behind why weâ€™re here on earth and what we should be doing with our time here. Call it spiritual, call it political, call it whatever you want: itâ€™s good shit, and itâ€™s concrete proof of Obongjayarâ€™s unrelenting and pure visionâ€”a brief yet ostensibly enticing insight into one of the most promising artists of our time right now. Need proof? Check out James Massiahâ€™s feature on Basseyâ€™s final track â€œGravity,â€ a bold, colorful soliloquy that takes in everything from huffing balloons and doing lines before being brought back down to the ground. â€”Ryan Bassil

Channeling the harrowing loneliness of 80s sci-fi aesthetics, the revolting underbelly of ASMR whispers, and the general conviction that sound is a force meant to be experienced physically, FÃ©licia Atkinsonâ€™s Hand in Hand can be a bit of an anxious listen. Funereal synthesizer drones crash into the animated found sounds of the everyday as the French multimedia artist whispers over it about desire, terror, and sometimes nothing much in particular (On â€œA House a Dance a Poem,â€ she enunciates haltingly, â€œslidingâ€¦glasssssâ€¦doors.â€) She trades most winningly in this sort of obliteration of meaningâ€”sound, word, and deed follow no obviously legible logic other than the collagist impulse of Atkinsonâ€™s ear for composition. Over the course of its runtime, Hand in Hand starts to feel like nothing means anything at allâ€”even the passages that were sorta easy to follow at firstâ€”which is a terrifying thought to have, even when youâ€™re not listening to synthesizer buzzing and splatting like a dentistâ€™s drill through soft tissue. â€”Colin Joyce

Punks be new wavers. Though Orion formed from fragments of Sydney punk bands with names like Whores, Low Life, Oily Boys, and M.O.B., their self-titled album draws from the melody, mood, and sensibility of pop acts such as New Order and Pet Shop Boys. Led by the emotive and sometimes sullen vocals of Yuta Matsumura, the synth- and guitar-based tracks can be both morose and joyous. Songs like â€œRed Lightsâ€ and â€œExecutionâ€ will have you dancing to them at the gig and staring at the wall and contemplating your existence while listening to them at home. This is DIY pop that is somber, atmospheric, and beautifully bruised. â€”Tim Scott

There are certain types of people who seem to be born to experience life in the toughest way possible. Sometimes itâ€™s a predetermined, almost genetic fateâ€”inescapable not just because of who you are but who your family is. Other times itâ€™s a product of a few poorly thought-out personal choices. For Jason Isbell, itâ€™s both, and the songwriter has made a career out of relaying his experiences to the rest of the world as a cautionary tale. This approach to storytelling makes his sixth record, The Nashville Sound, seem perhaps more politically charged than Isbell intended. On it, he moves away from soul-crushingly intimate songs (though â€œIf We Were Vampiresâ€ threatens to make even the happiest thingâ€”loveâ€”into its own kind of death sentence) and eyes the bigger picture. Now a father, Isbell is no longer focused on just himself and his life. Heâ€™s questioning everything through a radical light and learning to unlearn the tough lessons in order to teach the easier ones. â€”Annalise Domenighini

Writing a best-selling autobiography usually means youâ€™ve set your legacy in stone, and to an extent that is true for the man born Radric Davis. He is the Trap God, an antihero who birthed the current sound of Atlanta rap, who went to jail but then re-emerged as a wise, hit-making elder statesman. He has nothing left to prove, so he decided to casually bang out a studio session with the hottest beatmaker in the world and create Droptopwop, easily his strongest post-prison release to date. Metro Boominâ€™s demonic production spurs Gucci to relive his loose cannon past through some of his most expressive performances in years. The hook of â€œFinesse the Plug Interludeâ€ is a lazy drawl and he menacingly whispers sweet nothings on â€œHelpless.â€ Metro, meanwhile, becomes trap Mozart, pulling out demented chiptune synths on â€œThoâ€ and adorning 2 Chainz and Young Dolph in music box chimes on â€œBoth Eyes Closed.â€ Most of the material, however, pales in comparison to the mighty â€œMet Gala,â€ where Gucci and Offset go toe-to-toe with their flows over nothing but a tolling church bell and a landslide of 808s. Itâ€™s here where Gucciâ€™s music feels like it lives up to his outlaw legend once again. â€”Phil Witmer

I Love You Like a Brother showcases a sense of clarity in punk-pop auteur Alex Laheyâ€™s writing. She sings on â€œPerth Traumatic Stress Disorder,â€ â€œPerth is lucky that sheâ€™s pretty / Otherwise, Iâ€™d hate that city / The only place my heartâ€™s been torn in two,â€ before adding flatly, â€œAlways worth the lengthy flight.â€ Itâ€™s a moment that showcases Laheyâ€™s ability to vividly leverage moments of hurt alongside humor without coming off as indifferent or apathetic. Elsewhere, â€œI Havenâ€™t Been Taking Care of Myselfâ€ deftly dodges between toxic self-doubt and what happens when you project it onto the one you love (â€œMaybe thatâ€™s why you donâ€™t love me as much / I need to start taking care of myselfâ€). Laheyâ€™s complete command of specifying the little feelings between love and hateâ€”while having a bit of fun, of courseâ€”cement I Love You Like A Brother as one of the yearâ€™s best records. â€”Jabbari Weekes

Thereâ€™s no way else to put it: 2 Chainzâ€™s Pretty Girls Like Trap Music is a vibe. Maybe thatâ€™s a little on the nose (the albumâ€™s second single, of course, is the highly memeable, â€œItâ€™s a Vibeâ€). But thatâ€™s how 2 Chainz rolls. With Pretty Girls Like Trap Music, the elder statesman of hip-hop created a whole ambiance, complete with a real-live pink trap house to match the one on the album cover, a temporary pop-up in Atlanta that served as everything from an art gallery to a health clinic and is now back for the holidays. With this album, he was trying to communicate that heâ€™s more than just the guy with the incredible punchlines, though how can you resist lines like â€œmy pocket pregnant, donâ€™t want no abortionâ€ (â€œRiverdale Rdâ€) or â€œIâ€™m so high they might call a goaltendâ€ (â€œPoor Foolâ€).â€ Maybe itâ€™s predictable that 2 Chainz is endlessly charming, has wit for days, and makes songs like â€œ4AMâ€ that you relate to and donâ€™t relate to at once (Relatable: â€œdrop a pin, send a location.â€ Not relatable: Iâ€™ma pull up in that bullet-coupe spaceship). This album is full of bangers you want to listen to on a loop. Itâ€™s a vibe! And itâ€™s a good one. â€”Leslie Horn

The color that best describes emo-folk artist Phoebe Bridgersâ€™ debut album is blue. Itâ€™s in the mournful guitar line of opener â€œSmoke Signalsâ€ and the airiness of â€œMotion Sicknessâ€; on the chorus of â€œFuneral,â€ she even describes herself as â€œblue, all the time.â€ Suffice to say, blue is the color of sadness, and Stranger in the Alps is an album preoccupied with topics like depression, and deathâ€”but itâ€™s also the color of the sky, the sea, breath, and life itself, a duality reflected throughout the album. Without self-importance or unnecessary grandeur, Stranger in the Alps traverses what it means to be human: for every painful admission of loneliness, thereâ€™s a moment of connection, too. In an appealing, accessible style, Bridgers cuts through the matters that plague us most of all with an astounding clarity: to hear Stranger in the Alpsâ€”perhaps through headphones, clutching a warm drink on a cold dayâ€”is to have a quietly revelatory experience. â€”Lauren Oâ€™Neill

Mozzy has rapped 18 Tolstoy novels worth of introspective rhymes and detailed stories of gang life over the last few years. Gunplay holds a standing annual contract to slap the shit out of your jaw and remind you that you feel invincible when you hear his music. Naturally, they sound like they grew up rapping with one another. Soul-revealing, bone-rattling tracks like â€œThey Know,â€ â€œNever Had Shit,â€ and â€œWe Ainâ€™t Going Brokeâ€ reassure you that theyâ€™re some of the only rappers who can convincingly both tell you not to get blood on the work and make you empathize with a guy in prison who doesnâ€™t even have a girl to write, all while outdoing each otherâ€™s creativity and intensity. This year, rap had a ton of fun with the duo album, bringing together high-profile names for low-stakes oneupmanship, but no project executed more effectively than Dreadlocks & Headshots. After all, if you donâ€™t listen to rap to hear dudes rap fractals out of a song called â€œGangland,â€ what are you even doing with your life? â€”Trey Smith

Sunrotâ€™s debut, Sunnata, is anomalous even in a genre that celebrates the strange and unexpected. The North Jersey quartetâ€™s take on doom metal is so thoroughly corroded with harsh industrial elements that at times, itâ€™s reduced down to screaming noise, filtered through a nightmarish homemade vocal distortion mask. Though itâ€™s only the bandâ€™s first stab at a full-length, itâ€™s their fourth release overall, and it eclipses their promising earlier efforts. As Noisey noted back in August, â€œSunrot treads heavily at the crux between multiple ugly, noisy genres; their sludgy, industrial clamor borrows liberally from harsh noise and hateful drone, but makes plenty of space for riffsâ€”lumbering, distorted things that pound away at your eardrums like storm waves on a vanishing coastlineâ€”and vocalist Lexâ€™s emotional, pushed-to-the-edge howls.â€ Sunnata wouldâ€™ve been a no-brainer for a Best of 2017 list no matter who was behind the albumâ€™s creation, but the fact that it was made by a bunch of goofy, big-hearted Jersey kids warms our cold black hearts. â€”Kim Kelly

That Nadia Reidâ€™s melancholic folk-infused music comes from a place as naturally beautiful as Port Chalmers makes sense. The port of Dunedin, located at the southern tip of New Zealand, is remote and scenic and the perfect location for a such an introspective and meditative song as â€œThe Arrow and the Aim.â€ â€œRichardâ€ speaks of a relationship that is over. Richard â€œloved the sound of his own voice in the kitchen by the mirror,â€ sings Reid. Dickâ€™s gone but the kitchen, mirror, and emotion remain. While fellow Kiwis Aldous Harding and Lorde may outshine her, Reid has produced a stunning album in Preservation. â€”Tim Scott

Lil Peep is for people who earnestly listen to Take Off Your Pants And Jacket to get over the dissolution of a high school relationship, play MMORPG games, and reject outdoor activities in favor of talking to strangers on the internet. And for the multitudes of words that have been written about Peepâ€™s music over the last year or so, one fact seems to have been lost: itâ€™s not supposed to be cool. Itâ€™s music for losers, loners, and outcasts, and Come Over When Youâ€™re Sober (Part One) is impactful in its simplicity, fusing Blink-182 vocal melodies with cloud-rap beats and standing as the most accomplished and succinct example of his style and persona. The songs are about depression, loneliness, self-hate, and heartbreak, complicated themes boiled down to short-but-sweet mantras (â€œSometimes life gets fucked up / Thatâ€™s why we get fucked upâ€). A lot of those mantras come off as bittersweet following his tragic death, but they remain as relatable and escapist anthems for a generation that deals with its problems by going live on Instagram about them. Come Over When Youâ€™re Sober (Part One) is now a staple within a sub-genre it helped pioneer: intense and irresistible in its uniqueness, but also charged with excitement for what could have come after. â€”Emma Garland

Apparently thereâ€™s a whole conceit about â€œmathematical growth and decayâ€ at the heart of Gerald Donaldâ€™s new album as Dopplereffekt, but as with his previous work in Drexciya, you donâ€™t really need to understand the concept to appreciate whatâ€™s going on in the abstract instrumentals. Here, that means nine beatless, but still percussive pieces that send the aqueous electro heâ€™s known for making from underwater to outer space. Each piece is constructed simply, just a few synthesizer washes and jittery patches reacting volatilely with one another. The component parts are slow and staid mostly, but the way they play off each other gives each track and unsettling sort of combustion. Donald (working here under the pseudonym Rudolf Klorzeiger with a collaborator named To-Nhan) has a knack for knowing what elements will take an ambient piece and make it explode, and what can take something steely and turn it into gold. Forget math, Cellular Automata is alchemy. â€”Colin Joyce

Not that a take on black metal thatâ€™s this otherworldly and inventive needs a compelling creation myth, but the story behind Yellow Eyesâ€™ Immersion Trench Reverie only magnifies its strangeness. Before the New York brothers Will and Sam Skarstad decamped to the Connecticut cabin where they usually record, they spent a month together in Siberia, absorbing the wildness of its atmosphere. That period imbues the record with a sense of forebodingâ€”thereâ€™s field recordings of ringing bells, roving packs of wild dogs, and the chanting of a local choir. But it also just sort of makes sense that the duo would eventually end up there; their music has always shared quite a bit in common with the loneliness of Russiaâ€™s sparest realms. Itâ€™s not just the cold, itâ€™s the openness, the sense that pieces like â€œVelvet on the Hornsâ€ can sprint off into any direction, from sidewinding tremolo-picked riffs to uneasy ambience to steamrolling drum punishment all within a minute or two. Thereâ€™s a sense of possibility, that literally anything can happen, which is of course both uplifting and terrifying at the same time. â€”Colin Joyce

â€œSoothing,â€ the first song on Laura Marlingâ€™s sixth studio album, Semper Femina, begins with a brooding bassline. It pulses, serving as both a seduction and an instruction with Marling singing deeply, â€œI banish you with love.â€ The song, as sparse as she makes it, is very heavy. Marling is one of the most talentedâ€”and wisestâ€”songwriters of her generation; since emerging as a London teenager in 2008, sheâ€™s steadily gathered an audience enraptured by her tender gestures of love and loss, and the softness she shows us in her work. On Semper Feminaâ€”her most technically concise and shortest record to dateâ€”Marling reckons with femininity as a cultural product: what makes one feminine, and how do we metabolize it? Why and how is it gendered? The subject matter may sound hefty and academic, but Marling communicates it to us via swelling strings. Then thereâ€™s the tenderest tribute to her female friend on â€œNouel,â€ in which she sings, â€œShe speaks a word and it gently turns / To perfect metaphor/ She likes to say I only play / When I know what Iâ€™m playing for.â€ Similar to Marlingâ€™s work as a whole, Semper Femina is ultimately a place of refuge and knowledge. â€”Sarah MacDonald

From the deep hollers of Kentucky comes Tyler Childers, born and raised in coal-mining country to a deeply religious family, familiar with how even extreme poverty cannot prevent someone from experiencing absolute joy. Though Childers has been kicking around the greater Appalachian music scene for many years, Purgatory is his first foray into the mainstream eye. With its backwoods banjo and devilish fiddle, the record creates a supernatural reading of lifeâ€™s struggles. â€œWhitehouse Roadâ€ and â€œHonky Tonk Flameâ€ both provide different tellings of the same storyâ€”the story of someone who, for better or for worse, canâ€™t for the life of him give up on a dreamâ€”while â€œFeathered Indiansâ€ and â€œLady Mayâ€ are heartbreaking and candid depictions of the difficulty of balancing earthly vices with otherworldly experiences (in this case, absolute love). Where the record comes together is â€œUniversal Sound,â€ a reminder that no matter where we end up, thatâ€™s where we are, and ultimately life is a universal sound, not an individual one. â€”Annalise Domenighini

Much of Maya Bouldry-Morrisonâ€™s latest record as Octo Octa is suffused with an overwhelming lightness. Itâ€™s not that her music hadnâ€™t been beforeâ€”house music is one of those forms where even its more dour moments are attended to by a dogmatic blissâ€”but Where Are We Going? is something different. In an interview with the multidisciplinary artist Terre Thaemlitz, Bouldry-Morrison mused on the fact that her last LP Between Two Selves was a â€œcoded queer messageâ€ while this record is more â€œovert,â€ which could explain some of its openhearted charms. Itâ€™s joy unrestrained, expressed in dreamy vocal samples, creaky drum breaks and dizzy ambience (as on the winningly titled standout, â€œNo More Pain (Promises to a Younger Selfâ€). Sheâ€™s said that the later stages were informed by the strange experience of making such a record on the eve of the presidency of a hateful despot, but even the recordâ€™s wistful closing moments come with an uplifting accompaniment: the chatter of a voice posing a question â€œDo you feel better?â€ Where Are We Going? makes it feel like the answer could be yes. â€”Colin Joyce

Denver trio Primitive Man have spent the last five years building a fruitful DIY career out of their uncanny ability to harness the purest essence of nihilistic misery, and then inject it straight into the molten core of their tense, lumbering, sludge-splattered doom metal recordings. Theyâ€™re alarmingly prolific, as well; while their stunning 2017 LP, Caustic, marks only their second full-length, the band has also put out 11 other splits and singles since 2010. No rest for the wicked, indeed. On Caustic, burly vocalist and guitarist Ethan McCarthy rages against racism, corruption, structural inequality, and depression in his imposing roar, laying down juddering, noise-soaked riffs for the rhythm sectionâ€”drummer Joe Linden and bassist Jonathan Camposâ€”provide mephitic fuel for the blast furnace. The end result is as nasty as Satanâ€™s to-do list and heavy as a sack of molten leadâ€”a painful, carefully constructed document of grief and aggression. In year as dark and astonishingly fucked up as this oneâ€™s been, Primitive Man made sure to remind us: itâ€™s only going to get worse. â€”Kim Kelly

Birdie, the sophomore album from Modern Baseball singer/guitarist Jake Ewaldâ€™s new(ish) project Slaughter Beach, Dog, establishes that heâ€™s a man wise beyond his years. While Modern Baseball saw the 24-year-old cutting his teeth with poppy, coming-of-age emo songs, with Slaughter Beach, Dog he showcases an astonishingly rapid maturation as a songwriter and producer. He all but scraps the raucous rock formula that earned him a huge and rabid following, replacing it with softer, more patient mutations of folk and Shins-style indie-pop. With his heartfelt, reading-from-a-journal style of lyrical delivery, Ewald is quickly positioning himself as the Tumblr Generationâ€™s John K. Samson, and Birdie shows off an eclectic musical palette that songwriters twice his age would envy. â€”Dan Ozzi

The notion of finding strength in being vulnerable is not a new one, especially not to Caroline Spence. Spades and Roses, the Nashville-based songwriterâ€™s second record, takes that idea and expands it, tapping into an ancient tradition of finding strength grounded in femininity and toughening up. Spence paints a picture of a woman caught in the middle of reckoning with herself as an individual and as a product of a life that maybe never planned to include her.
